abstract_summ: Though these guidelines provide strategies to deal with trauma and orthopaedic surgery management in the present scenario, once the COVID-19 pandemic stabilizes, restarting elective orthopaedic surgery and managing delayed trauma conditions in evolving health care systems is going to be a profound task.Four topics were addressed: (1) origin and surgical experience of the participant (four questions); (2) potential disruption of arthroplasty surgeries (12 questions); (3) influence of the COVID-19 pandemic on the particular arthroplasty surgeon (four questions); (4) a matrix provided 14 different arthroplasty surgeries and the participant was asked to state whether dedicated surgery was stopped, delayed or cancelled.METHODS: As we begin to emerge from the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic, we need to plan the sustainable resumption of elective procedures.CONCLUSIONS: Few states have published guidelines specific to orthopaedic surgery during the COVID-19 outbreak, leaving hospital systems and surgeons with the responsibility of balancing the benefits of surgery with the risks to public health.Hospitals have been restructured to provide the best care to COVID-19 patients while adopting preventive strategies not to spread the infection among healthcare providers and patients affected by other diseases.
title_summ: The Arthroplasty Community and the COVID-19 PandemicA Review of State Guidelines for Elective Orthopaedic Procedures During the COVID-19 OutbreakThe role of the orthopaedic surgeon in the COVID-19 era: cautions and perspectivesThe COVID-19 outbreak in Italy: perspectives from an orthopaedic hospitalRapid Decline in Online Search Queries for Hip and Knee Replacements Concurrent with the COVID-19 PandemicDisruption of Arthroplasty Practice in an Orthopedic Center in Northern Italy During the Coronavirus Disease 2019 PandemicEconomic Recovery Following the COVID-19 Pandemic: Resuming Elective Orthopaedic Surgery and Total Joint ArthroplastyPost COVID-19: Planning strategies to resume orthopaedic surgery –challenges and considerationsManagement of orthopaedic and traumatology patients during the Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in northern ItalyThe Effect of The COVID-19 Pandemic On Electively Scheduled HIP and KNEE Arthroplasty Patients in THE United StatesTriaging Total Hip Arthroplasty During the COVID-19 PandemicScoring system to triage patients for spine surgery in the setting of limited resources:The impact of the novel coronavirus on trauma and orthopaedics in the UK.Disruption of joint arthroplasty services in Europe during the COVID-19 pandemic: an online survey within the European Hip Society (EHS) and the European Knee Associates (EKA)An overview of the situation of hand surgery in Spain during the peak of COVID-19 pandemicHumanitarian Needs:Application to the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond
title_abstract_phrases: Though these guidelines provide strategies to deal with trauma and orthopaedic surgery management in the present scenario, once the COVID-19 pandemic stabilizes, restarting elective orthopaedic surgery and managing delayed trauma conditions in evolving health care systems is going to be a profound task.The Effect of The COVID-19 Pandemic On Electively Scheduled HIP and KNEE Arthroplasty Patients in THE United StatesIn response to the COVID-19 pandemic, US hospitals stopped performing elective procedures.Four topics were addressed: (1) origin and surgical experience of the participant (four questions); (2) potential disruption of arthroplasty surgeries (12 questions); (3) influence of the COVID-19 pandemic on the particular arthroplasty surgeon (four questions); (4) a matrix provided 14 different arthroplasty surgeries and the participant was asked to state whether dedicated surgery was stopped, delayed or cancelled.METHODS: As we begin to emerge from the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic, we need to plan the sustainable resumption of elective procedures.Hospitals have been restructured to provide the best care to COVID-19 patients while adopting preventive strategies not to spread the infection among healthcare providers and patients affected by other diseases.
